title: Man Starts Fundraising Campaign to Fund Fundraising Campaigns
text:
Man Starts Fundraising Campaign to Fund Fundraising Campaigns
In what may be the most meta fundraising initiative of the decade, local entrepreneur Brad Moneybags launched a campaign to fund future campaigns.
“I realized people love giving money, but only if it’s organized by someone else,” Moneybags explained. “So I’m creating the ultimate fundraising fund.”
Supporters are reportedly impressed by the efficiency and innovation of raising funds to raise more funds—a process some are calling “profit inception.”

title: Local School Sells Naming Rights to Cafeteria
text:
Local School Sells Naming Rights to Cafeteria
In a groundbreaking education-meets-advertising initiative, Lincoln High has sold the naming rights to its cafeteria.
Students now eat lunch under banners proudly sponsored by SnackCorp™, SodaBlast™, and MysteryEnergyDrink™. “We thought it would motivate students to learn,” said the principal. “Who doesn’t want to study when every bite comes with a brand endorsement?”
Parents are reportedly thrilled that their children are being prepared for a corporate future—one lunch at a time.

title: Mayor Turns City Hall into Luxury Hotel
text:
Mayor Turns City Hall into Luxury Hotel
In an unprecedented move blending politics and real estate, the mayor has converted City Hall into a five-star luxury hotel.
Residents are reportedly confused about where to pay their parking tickets, but investors are ecstatic. “We see untapped potential in civic real estate,” said one hotel manager. “Why have a council meeting when you can have a spa day?”
The public is encouraged to book early, especially for the penthouse, formerly the mayor’s office, now offering skyline views and complimentary lobbying advice.

title: Corporation Discovers New Mineral: Pure Capitalism
text:
Corporation Discovers New Mineral: Pure Capitalism
Scientists were stunned when researchers at MegaCorp Labs announced the discovery of a new mineral: Pure Capitalism.
The mineral is reportedly shiny, highly malleable, and incredibly rare—perfect for forging new business ventures and stock portfolios. “We’ve already patented it,” said a spokesperson. “It’s amazing what you can do when the planet is just a resource for profit.”
Environmentalists are unconcerned, citing their limited capacity to compete with billion-dollar marketing campaigns.

title: Standing Rock: A Pipeline of Profits
text:
Standing Rock: A Pipeline of Profits
In what analysts have proudly labeled a breakthrough in combining environmental denial with financial ambition, the Standing Rock protests have reminded the nation of a simple principle: people are important until they interfere with revenue.
While hundreds gathered to defend sacred land and clean water, corporate leaders stayed focused on the real issue, which was the projected gain on next year’s earnings report. “We absolutely hear the concerns of Indigenous communities,” said one executive from a conference room decorated with inspirational posters about synergy, “which is why we scheduled a meeting to consider scheduling another meeting about it.”
Protesters showed up with determination, handmade signs, and a sense of responsibility for future generations. They were met with the unstoppable force of investment capital, which arrives quietly and grows loudly. Pipelines do not wait for ethics reviews. They only wait for construction permits and favorable market conditions.
Local officials explained that they deeply respect cultural heritage but also respect the budget surplus the pipeline might bring. “Water is precious,” said one official while reviewing financial charts, “but these revenue projections are truly beautiful.”
Investors held early celebrations, toasting with champagne and discussing how efficiently profits can travel when obstacles like morality are removed. The choice between people and profit has never been difficult for them. Profit never argues back and always shows up on time.
